title: Mediation
introduction:
Parents can use the help of a mediator if they can’t agree on some issues. Mediators won’t take sides or give legal advice but will show all options available.

Mediation works for most people - two thirds of couples who attend reach an agreement.

Parents must first meet with a mediator to check if it’s right for them. This is called a Mediation Information and Assessment Meeting (MIAM).

Find out more about mediation

cost.info:
The average cost of a mediation session is £80.
How many sessions you have depends on the amount of issues you want to discuss.

If you don’t work, or are on a low income, you may be able to get legal aid

Check if you can get legal aid

helpline.info:
01920 443 834 (Family Mediation Council)
Calls charged at a local rate

cons.text: requires high level of parent co-operation
agreements aren’t legally binding

title: Collaborative Law
introduction:
Collaborative lawyers work with both parents to try and resolve their issues without having to go to court. After each parent appoints a lawyer everyone meets to negotiate face to face.

Negotiations are direct and efficient and give parents the opportunity to resolve issues in an amicable way.

Collaborative law is about wanting what’s best for the whole family. Both parents must be able to communicate with each other and need to go into it with an open mind.

Find out more about collaborative law

cost.info: Costs are hard to estimate, but could be in the region of £8,000 to £15,000.

duration.info: There’s no timetable - how long the process takes is up to you and the other parent.

pros.text: everyone is committed to not going to court
quicker and less stressful than court
good for children to see their parents working together

cons.text: expensive process
parents must trust each other equally

title: Family Arbitration
introduction:
Family arbitration is a type of dispute resolution that some people use instead of going to court. Both parents appoint an independent arbitrator who will make a decision based on relevant facts about the case.

The arbitrator’s decision is called an ‘determination’ and is final and legally binding.

For arbitration to work both parents need to be able to communicate with each other. They won’t need to meet face-to-face but will need to agree on some issues before the process starts.

Find out more about family arbitration

cost.info: The cost varies from case to case and can depend on where parents live and the experience of the arbitrator.

duration.info: How long it takes will depend on the case.

pros.text: quicker and cheaper than going to court
parents choose what issues to resolve

cons.text: expensive process
requires high level of parent co-operation
process isn’t flexible - the arbitrator’s decision is final

title: Going to court
introduction:
In most cases going to court to make child arrangements should be the last resort. It can take a long time and be an expensive and stressful process, especially for the children.

There are some situations when you must go to court to make child arrangements.

Parents should consider other options like mediation or collaborative law before applying for a court order.

Find out more about going to court

cost.info: Depends on how complicated the case is.

duration.info: The average court case for child arrangements is 26 weeks.

cons.text: can be expensive
court process takes a long time
less parental control - a judge will make the decision
more stressful for children
increased chance of parent conflict
most people won’t get legal aid for solicitor fees

title: Lawyer mediation
introduction:
Lawyer assisted mediation is slightly different to standard mediation. In this process parents still use the help of a mediator but both their lawyers are also present.

Parents who use lawyer assisted mediation tend to because their case is complex or there are a lot of issues at stake.

The mediator is in charge of the whole process and will direct the parents and their lawyers to help.

Find out more about lawyer mediation

cost.info: This will depend on the day rate of the lawyers. Ask for a quote before you proceed.

duration.info: The process usually takes place over one long session, rather than through several short mediation sessions.

helpline.info:
01920 443 834 (Family Mediation Council)
Calls charged at local rate

pros.text: useful if the case is complex
helps parents who may be nervous about negotiating
lawyers draw up legally binding agreement

cons.text: presence of lawyers makes it expensive
requires parental cooperation

title: Negotiation between parents
introduction:
The cheapest and easiest way to make arrangements for children is for parents to negotiate between themselves.

However, this can only work if the separation is amicable and both parents already agree on the majority of issues.

Find out more about negotiating yourselves

duration.info: There’s no timetable - how long the process takes is up to the parents.

helpline.info:
There are several tools and services that can help you:

  • Parenting plan: https://www.cafcass.gov.uk/grown-ups/parenting-plan.aspx
  • Negotiating techniques tool: http://www.separatedfamilies.info/home/parenting-apart/negotiations/
  • Putting kids first plan: http://www.splittingup-putkidsfirst.org.uk/home
  • Arrange child maintenance yourself: https://www.gov.uk/arranging-child-maintenance-yourself

pros.text: lots of free tools and services to help

cons.text: agreements aren’t legally binding
parents must be on good terms with each other

title: Solicitor negotiation
introduction:
Solicitor negotiation is like collaborative law in that both parties try to resolve issues out of court. The difference is that the parents don’t meet to negotiate - this is all done by the solicitors.

Parents who use solicitors to negotiate tend to because their relationship is difficult, or there’s a lack of trust, following separation.

Find out more about solicitor negotiation

cost.info: Costs are hard to estimate, but could be in the region of £8,000 to £15,000.

duration.info: There’s no timetable - how long the process takes is down to how quickly you and the other parent can come to an agreement.

pros.text: everyone is committed to not going to court
parents don’t have to deal directly with each other

cons.text: it can be seen as a confrontational approach
parents can sometimes feel they’re not in control
it can be expensive
